pros: They encourage employees to work from home. Benefits were decent.
cons: Former company was bought out and instantly became part of Oracle without much forethought on either end. Oracle is excellent at selling product, but lacks with support. As a result, our team dealt mainly with unhappy customers who no longer had the same essential support from prior company to run their businesses 24/7. While the support infrastructure went south, the support fees climbed, which further upset customers which was understandable and sympathized with them, but not much we were able to do as everything came from corp, which should have been left with our specific team handling that vertical.

review_title: Lots of perks and opportunities for internal mobility
pros:
- Very competitive compensation package including stock options
- Amazing benefits that you would expect at a huge company
- A culture around learning and development with great resources like LinkedIn Learning, access to Harvard Business Review, hundreds of curated learning paths, etc.
- Recent push to encourage employees to pursue opportunities outside their department but within the company, while providing the leadership guidance and technical tools to make this easy
- Remote-friendly
cons:
- I've had colleagues who've lost their job every year since I've been here (terminations and reductions in force or RIFs)
- Things move pretty slowly
- Lots and lots of processes

review_title: Has the upside of being a part of the Oracle family; but uses legacy technology
pros:
Falling under the umbrella of Oracle, the organization gives you MNC perks. The Oracle access card can be used at any of the regional offices.
Facilities at Oracle Tech Hub can be availed.
The office interiors and general perks are as good as other MNCs and there are 11 total holidays available in a year.
cons:
They make dry promotions. Bonus is variable, and subject to the business of the region you're working for. Even when your performance remains same, if you shift regions that you're working for, your bonus may be affected.
They majorly use legacy PL/SQL technology to handle Flexcube related things. As a consultant, there isn't much progress in the first two years with the organizations. The tools they use are also pretty outdated.

review_title: This company is not about pay and related benefits
pros:
For most of the teams, the work pressure is lower compared to other contemporary companies.
Management usually is open for new ideas to improve productivity.
Good culture for WFH, though no official policies are present, with a valid case there are usually no questions asked.
cons:
Have no proper logic of pay increase. The increase in pay for a regular employee will never even meet the basic inflation rate. Hugely dependent on the immediate management even for these minimal benefits. Folks usually resort to reducing their performance for the same and company is usually fine with this unless it impacts deliverables very severely.
No pretense of any additional goodies or encouragement for high performers.

Techstack is primitive in most teams. And the struggle is always there for a minor improvement in this.

review_title: Attrition has been high due to recent events and no pay raise
pros:
Great people if you find the right organization to work with
Oracle is a good stepping stone if you're out of college
Health Benefits are great
cons:
Oracle decided to move HQ to Austin, TX which became effective late 2020. It was planned a long time ago so nothing to be angry there. Oracle is backfilling any departures in Austin, TX where possible. TX is employer friendly compared to CA. 

My review is from a non-OCI / non-engineering role -- this might not be applicable to you. Oracle is known for no pay raises. You can google it and it would be the top result. The average length of employees is around 2-3 years because they realized.. wow it is true. Time to find a better paying job. I have seen ex-coworkers get 40% raises by accepting outside jobs. I did the same. 

What's maddening is when I discussed pay with a peer.. I discovered that as a new hire.. I was paid more than him and he had been there 4 years already. Oracle doesn't value talent or loyalty. 

I have seen people request a match to stay but HR would say no. Your management chain will have no power. However, they would hire a total newbie for the pay that the person requested.. Oracle cannot retain talent. On blind -- I have seen someone polled offers between google and Oracle. all the Oracle employees said choose google.. you can chill and get pay raises. lolll it's funny how all oracle employees were on the same page. doesn't look good externally. 

Advice for anyone that wants a raise at Oracle -- apply to another position internally. That's the only way.

job_title: Cloud Sales Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: None that I can think of
cons:
They offer you a high OTE then they make your quota so high you can’t attain it. Then they cap you at 125%. Then, they don’t pay you the other half of your income. Then in the final quarter they make it so you get paid a minimal amount of what was owed to you from your first year’s quota but make you stay until the pay out date or they REFUSE to pay you at all. This company does not pay two week notices FYI. They do not value their employees or treat them well enough to not have a high turnover rate. 

On top of all of this, you will deal with internal oracle issues including but not limited to: CRM crashing, oracle collections harassing your customers, Internal competition, hazing from management, micromanagement, no visibility into install bases, Oracle interfering with deals to make it impossible for you to do your job correctly, demotions as soon as you sign on and honestly yet unfortunately the list goes on. 

Please beware of this company. Take notes that the culture is unbearable and they are evil. Don’t be fooled by the high OTE. Anywhere is better than Oracle by 100000000%. I wouldn’t wish this company on my worst enemy is how bad it was. Absolute torture.

pros:
I worked at Oracle for 3.5+ years. Started in the Class Of program when it included a trip to California. The company did a great job of introducing everyone to tech sales. Pre-Covid, Class Of was a good way to make friends and score some freebies. 

The people are one of Oracle's best assets. It's easy to network and make friends since most people are willing to help and don't act too pretentious.

You get to choose from a number of locations across the country. However, salaries are fixed so your dollar will probably go farther in Austin than in Santa Monica.

Bonuses/Commission rates used to be better and promotions used to be plentiful. It was fairly common for a BDC to get promoted to a closing role after 1+ year in seat. Wasn't unheard of for recent college graduates to be making close to 6 figures.

Benefits are pretty solid, nothing to complain about here.

Sales training is top-notch. However, only recently did the company start caring about giving its salespeople a strong technical foundation.

Overall, a lot of Oracle's pros can be found at any other large tech company.
cons:
Oracle is a behemoth of a company. You're just a number and any recognition you'll receive for doing a good job will be shortly met with a "what have you done for me lately?" mentality from your boss/director. 

Decision-making is a privilege reserved solely for upper management who rarely if ever step foot on the sales floor. For example, FY20 brought sweeping changes to OD Sales, with tons of people demoted without notice. I had 6 different managers my final year at the company. Sales here is a total revolving door.

Promotions are much harder to come by now as Covid led to several hiring freezes. The company would rather hire more Class Ofs for less money than promote internally or hire from the outside. Speaking of which, every account has upwards of 50 sales reps all calling into the same DBA, IT Manager, etc. so that by the time you reach out, you'll most likely be hung up on or sent straight to voicemail.

With promotions come minuscule 5% salary increases and unreasonable sales targets and commission rates.

BDCs, Inside Sales, and Field Sales, are often pitted against each other due to asinine territory management plans. Instead of working together to sell across product verticals, sales reps have to horde opporunity intelligence to ensure they can hit their quotas.

While Oracle does well in HW, On premise DB, and some SaaS, its PaaS & IaaS offerings are sorely lacking and the pressure to compete with the likes of AWS and Azure falls, unfortunately, on the sales reps.

While Oracle may be a well-known name to add to a resume, I'd highly suggest looking elsewhere. Or, at the very least, not spending too much time here.

review_title: Incredible for learning - Poor Treatment of Employees
pros:
1. Such an incredible place to learn - NetSuite puts a ton of pressure on their entry level analysts to learn and learn fast, I think that if you want a challenge this job will give it to you. You'll be really stressed your first year trying to learn everything and to be a good consultant but the amount you learn in your first year is insurmountable compared to other jobs

2. Very little micro-managing - if you like to take on leadership and do your things yourself NetSuite doesn't micro manage - in fact your manager will probably never even know a fraction of the things you're doing most of the day. Definitely a pro if you don't like to be micro-managed a con if you want to have a relationship with your manager

3. Heavy exposure to many lines of business - depending on what you specialize in, NetSuite provides you great exposure to many different types and kinds of businesses through their "shared resource pool"
cons:
1. Isolating - very little connection between managers/co-workers/project managers. You feel really distant from management and your "manager" doesn't even really know what you're up to unless you're in trouble. Oracle doesn't do anything to help foster a connection between leadership and their employees.

2. Very little work-life balance - expect to work weekends, late nights, and not get paid overtime until after your first year. Your PTO and vacation days are counted against your utilization so basically they inevitably discourage you from using PTO as your utilization is the key metric they look at for promotions. Expect to give your life and soul to NetSuite for your first 2 years if you end up staying that long

3. Over-Utilized and Underpaid - compared to other firms oracle overworks their tenured consultants while consistently underpaying them. You won't get a bonus, you won't get a pay raise until they promote you - it's really corporate and you can't do anything about it (no negotiations, "it's just how it is")

4. Retention - so many people leave and management doesn't do anything to acknowledge the lack of retention

review_title: Difficulties of pivoting from traditional enterprise on-premise software to cloud-based services
job_title: Vice President of Engineering in Redwood City, CA
pros: Oracle is focused on enterprise business software pivoting to cloud based software services and has invested heavily in cloud for the last 5+ years. Although it is late to the cloud, it should not be discounted as we are still early in cloud based services
cons:
1. Lack of earlier investments in cloud causes urgency in time-to-market of its cloud based services
2. Time-to-market causes short cuts to its engineering fundamentals
3. Top-down approach to engineering innovation - which kills true innovation
4. Pre-mature optimization - too focused on common engineering processes between newly developing / newly developed services, rather than enabling new services to be deployed

review_title: Oracle is an accounting-focused company, not a sales focused comany
pros:
Lots of spots to hide out and collect a base. If your idea of "sales" is "Audit Bargain Close" (google it) and you enjoy parsing through contracts to move the customer spend from one bucket to another, then this is the place for you.

Upward mobility because of high turnover.

You'll also get a big pay bump when you leave.
cons:
Go-to-market is terrible. Over half of reps won't even get to 10% of their number. 90% won't even get to 75% of their number. The outliers who hit their number generally do so when an existing customer naturally expands and the "Audit Bargain Close" process "works". This low attainment is despite the org itself hitting it's number most quarters. Which, mathematically, means that quotas are over-assigned by 4-6x most years. The solution year after year isn't that Oracle's GTM needs to change, it's that they must have hundreds of bad sales reps, thus the high "warm body" churn rates. 

Further disincentives to collaborate, if there is a co-prime, you are cut off at a certain threshold. In other words, you don't want to work a deal "too big" or it will get taken away. This leads to poor communication and confusion of the prospect/customer. 

Churn and burn culture with a warm body in place. Oracle treats sales as a cost, not an investment. No incentive to cross sell or collaborate with your co-workers. This leads to a high loss rate to competitors who sell strategically. It also leads to a dishonest work environment in terms of deal collaboration. Close rate is around 10% mind you. 

Oracle rewards Audit Bargain Close and moving a customers spend from one bucket to another and neglects any kind of incentive to find genuine new revenue.

Vast majority of sales managers and even VPs have never sold genuine net new revenue, but got to where they are by the same Audit Bargain Close methodology, reading Oracle contracts to exploit the comp plan, or have managed KPI-based sales "support orgs" and somehow moved into managing sales. Thus, they have no real ideas of how to find new revenue. Oracle's revenue hasn't grown in 8 years, so obviously no one is actually selling genuine net new revenue. High customer churn because Oracle would rather pay audit jockeys to screw over customers than hire enough customer success managers.



TL;DR, is this the kind of company you want to "sell" for?

Oracle's revenue hasn't grown in 8 years, yet EPS has.  High churn and low sales payouts (due to most reps not even remotely getting to their targets despite the org number as a whole being 100%+).

Oracle has been sued multiple times for "Audit Bargain Close" sales tactics.  This leads to high customer churn because Oracle doesn't understand that modern technology isn't as monolithic or hard to remove as it was in the 90s.  

There is an entire industry dedicated to servicing Oracle customers and protecting them from over usage and being audited.

This is not a sales company, it is a legal/accounting company.  It's a shame because the technology itself is world class.
